contents.verseText: Righteousness exalts a nation, but sin is a disgrace to any people.
contents: Righteousness exalts a nation,
but sin is a disgrace to any people.

contents.verseText: A king delights in a wise servant, but his anger falls on the shameful.
contents: A king delights in a wise servant,
but his anger falls on the shameful.

s1: A Gentle Answer Turns Away Wrath

contents.verseText: A gentle answer turns away wrath, but a harsh word stirs up anger.
contents: A gentle answer turns away wrath,
but a harsh word stirs up anger.

contents.verseText: The tongue of the wise commends knowledge, but the mouth of the fool spouts folly.
contents: The tongue of the wise commends knowledge,
but the mouth of the fool spouts folly.

contents.verseText: The eyes of the LORD are in every place, observing the evil and the good.
contents: The eyes of the LORD are in every place,
observing the evil and the good.

contents.verseText: A soothing tongue is a tree of life, but a perverse tongue crushes the spirit.
contents: A soothing tongue is a tree of life,
but a perverse tongue crushes the spirit.

contents.verseText: A fool rejects his father’s discipline, but whoever heeds correction is prudent.
contents: A fool rejects his father’s discipline,
but whoever heeds correction is prudent.

contents.verseText: The house of the righteous has great treasure, but the income of the wicked is trouble.
contents: The house of the righteous has great treasure,
but the income of the wicked is trouble.

contents.verseText: The lips of the wise spread knowledge, but not so the hearts of fools.
contents: The lips of the wise spread knowledge,
but not so the hearts of fools.

contents.verseText: The sacrifice of the wicked is detestable to the LORD, but the prayer of the upright is His delight.
contents: The sacrifice of the wicked is detestable to the LORD,
but the prayer of the upright is His delight.

contents.verseText: The LORD detests the way of the wicked, but He loves those who pursue righteousness.
contents: The LORD detests the way of the wicked,
but He loves those who pursue righteousness.

contents.verseText: Discipline is harsh for him who leaves the path; he who hates correction will die.
contents: Discipline is harsh for him who leaves the path;
he who hates correction will die.

contents.verseText: Sheol and Abaddon lie open before the LORD—how much more the hearts of men!
contents: Sheol and Abaddon

footnote.ft: Or Death and Destruction

contents: lie open before the LORD—
how much more the hearts of men!

contents.verseText: A mocker does not love to be reproved, nor will he consult the wise.
contents: A mocker does not love to be reproved,
nor will he consult the wise.

contents.verseText: A joyful heart makes a cheerful countenance, but sorrow of the heart crushes the spirit.
contents: A joyful heart makes a cheerful countenance,
but sorrow of the heart crushes the spirit.

contents.verseText: A discerning heart seeks knowledge, but the mouth of a fool feeds on folly.
contents: A discerning heart seeks knowledge,
but the mouth of a fool feeds on folly.

contents.verseText: All the days of the oppressed are bad, but a cheerful heart has a continual feast.
contents: All the days of the oppressed are bad,
but a cheerful heart has a continual feast.

contents.verseText: Better a little with the fear of the LORD than great treasure with turmoil.
contents: Better a little with the fear of the LORD
than great treasure with turmoil.

contents.verseText: Better a dish of vegetables where there is love than a fattened ox with hatred.
contents: Better a dish of vegetables where there is love
than a fattened ox with hatred.

contents.verseText: A hot-tempered man stirs up strife, but he who is slow to anger calms dispute.
contents: A hot-tempered man stirs up strife,
but he who is slow to anger calms dispute.

contents.verseText: The way of the slacker is like a hedge of thorns, but the path of the upright is a highway.
contents: The way of the slacker is like a hedge of thorns,
but the path of the upright is a highway.

contents.verseText: A wise son brings joy to his father, but a foolish man despises his mother.
contents: A wise son brings joy to his father,
but a foolish man despises his mother.

contents.verseText: Folly is joy to one who lacks judgment, but a man of understanding walks a straight path.
contents: Folly is joy to one who lacks judgment,
but a man of understanding walks a straight path.

contents.verseText: Plans fail for lack of counsel, but with many advisers they succeed.
contents: Plans fail for lack of counsel,
but with many advisers they succeed.

contents.verseText: A man takes joy in a fitting reply—and how good is a timely word!
contents: A man takes joy in a fitting reply—
and how good is a timely word!

contents.verseText: The path of life leads upward for the wise, that he may avoid going down to Sheol.
contents: The path of life leads upward for the wise,
that he may avoid going down to Sheol.

contents.verseText: The LORD tears down the house of the proud, but He protects the boundaries of the widow.
contents: The LORD tears down the house of the proud,
but He protects the boundaries of the widow.

contents.verseText: The LORD detests the thoughts of the wicked, but the words of the pure are pleasant to Him.
contents: The LORD detests the thoughts of the wicked,
but the words of the pure are pleasant to Him.

contents.verseText: He who is greedy for unjust gain brings trouble on his household, but he who hates bribes will live.
contents: He who is greedy for unjust gain brings trouble on his household,
but he who hates bribes will live.

contents.verseText: The heart of the righteous ponders how to answer, but the mouth of the wicked blurts out evil.
contents: The heart of the righteous ponders how to answer,
but the mouth of the wicked blurts out evil.

contents.verseText: The LORD is far from the wicked, but He hears the prayer of the righteous.
contents: The LORD is far from the wicked,
but He hears the prayer of the righteous.

contents.verseText: The light of the eyes cheers the heart, and good news nourishes the bones.
contents: The light of the eyes cheers the heart,
and good news nourishes the bones.

contents.verseText: He who listens to life-giving reproof will dwell among the wise.
contents: He who listens to life-giving reproof
will dwell among the wise.

contents.verseText: He who ignores discipline despises himself, but whoever heeds correction gains understanding.
contents: He who ignores discipline despises himself,
but whoever heeds correction gains understanding.

contents.verseText: The fear of the LORD is the instruction of wisdom, and humility comes before honor.
contents: The fear of the LORD is the instruction of wisdom,
and humility comes before honor.

s1: The Reply of the Tongue Is from the LORD

contents.verseText: The plans of the heart belong to man, but the reply of the tongue is from the LORD.
contents: The plans of the heart belong to man,
but the reply of the tongue is from the LORD.

contents.verseText: All a man’s ways are pure in his own eyes, but his motives are weighed out by the LORD.
contents: All a man’s ways are pure in his own eyes,
but his motives are weighed out by the LORD.

contents.verseText: Commit your works to the LORD and your plans will be achieved.
contents: Commit your works to the LORD
and your plans will be achieved.

contents.verseText: The LORD has made everything for His purpose—even the wicked for the day of disaster.
contents: The LORD has made everything for His purpose—
even the wicked for the day of disaster.

contents.verseText: Everyone who is proud in heart is detestable to the LORD; be assured that he will not go unpunished.
contents: Everyone who is proud in heart is detestable to the LORD;
be assured that he will not go unpunished.

contents.verseText: By loving devotion and faithfulness iniquity is atoned for, and by the fear of the LORD one turns aside from evil.
contents: By loving devotion and faithfulness iniquity is atoned for,
and by the fear of the LORD one turns aside from evil.

contents.verseText: When a man’s ways please the LORD, He makes even the man’s enemies live at peace with him.
contents: When a man’s ways please the LORD,
He makes even the man’s enemies live at peace with him.

contents.verseText: Better a little with righteousness than great gain with injustice.
contents: Better a little with righteousness
than great gain with injustice.

contents.verseText: A man’s heart plans his course, but the LORD determines his steps.
contents: A man’s heart plans his course,
but the LORD determines his steps.

contents.verseText: A divine verdict is on the lips of a king; his mouth must not betray justice.
contents: A divine verdict is on the lips of a king;
his mouth must not betray justice.

contents.verseText: Honest scales and balances are from the LORD; all the weights in the bag are His concern.
contents: Honest scales and balances are from the LORD;
all the weights in the bag are His concern.

contents.verseText: Wicked behavior is detestable to kings, for a throne is established through righteousness.
contents: Wicked behavior is detestable to kings,
for a throne is established through righteousness.

contents.verseText: Righteous lips are a king’s delight, and he who speaks honestly is beloved.
contents: Righteous lips are a king’s delight,
and he who speaks honestly is beloved.

contents.verseText: The wrath of a king is a messenger of death, but a wise man will pacify it.
contents: The wrath of a king is a messenger of death,
but a wise man will pacify it.

contents.verseText: When a king’s face brightens, there is life; his favor is like a rain cloud in spring.
contents: When a king’s face brightens, there is life;
his favor is like a rain cloud in spring.

contents.verseText: How much better to acquire wisdom than gold! To gain understanding is more desirable than silver.
contents: How much better to acquire wisdom than gold!
To gain understanding is more desirable than silver.

contents.verseText: The highway of the upright leads away from evil; he who guards his way protects his life.
contents: The highway of the upright leads away from evil;
he who guards his way protects his life.

contents.verseText: Pride goes before destruction, and a haughty spirit before a fall.
contents: Pride goes before destruction,
and a haughty spirit before a fall.

contents.verseText: It is better to be lowly in spirit among the humble than to divide the spoil with the proud.
contents: It is better to be lowly in spirit among the humble
than to divide the spoil with the proud.

contents.verseText: Whoever heeds instruction will find success, and blessed is he who trusts in the LORD.
contents: Whoever heeds instruction will find success,

footnote.ft: Or Whoever speaks prudently will find what is good

contents: and blessed is he who trusts in the LORD.

contents.verseText: The wise in heart are called discerning, and pleasant speech promotes instruction.
contents: The wise in heart are called discerning,
and pleasant speech promotes instruction.

contents.verseText: Understanding is a fountain of life to its possessor, but the discipline of fools is folly.
contents: Understanding is a fountain of life to its possessor,
but the discipline of fools is folly.

contents.verseText: The heart of the wise man instructs his mouth and adds persuasiveness to his lips.
contents: The heart of the wise man instructs his mouth
and adds persuasiveness to his lips.

contents.verseText: Pleasant words are a honeycomb, sweet to the soul and healing to the bones.
contents: Pleasant words are a honeycomb,
sweet to the soul and healing to the bones.

contents.verseText: There is a way that seems right to a man, but its end is the way of death.
contents: There is a way that seems right to a man,
but its end is the way of death.

contents.verseText: A worker’s appetite works for him because his hunger drives him onward.
contents: A worker’s appetite works for him
because his hunger drives him onward.

contents.verseText: A worthless man digs up evil, and his speech is like a scorching fire.
contents: A worthless man digs up evil,
and his speech

footnote.ft: Or and what is on his lips

contents: is like a scorching fire.

contents.verseText: A perverse man spreads dissension, and a gossip divides close friends.
contents: A perverse man spreads dissension,
and a gossip divides close friends.

contents.verseText: A violent man entices his neighbor and leads him down a path that is not good.
contents: A violent man entices his neighbor
and leads him down a path that is not good.

contents.verseText: He who winks his eye devises perversity; he who purses his lips is bent on evil.
contents: He who winks his eye devises perversity;
he who purses his lips is bent on evil.

contents.verseText: Gray hair is a crown of glory; it is attained along the path of righteousness.
contents: Gray hair is a crown of glory;
it is attained along the path of righteousness.

contents.verseText: He who is slow to anger is better than a warrior, and he who controls his temper is greater than one who captures a city.
contents: He who is slow to anger is better than a warrior,
and he who controls his temper is greater than one who captures a city.

contents.verseText: The lot is cast into the lap, but its every decision is from the LORD.
contents: The lot is cast into the lap,
but its every decision is from the LORD.

s1: Better a Dry Morsel in Quietness

contents.verseText: Better a dry morsel in quietness than a house full of feasting with strife.
contents: Better a dry morsel in quietness
than a house full of feasting

footnote.ft: Or sacrifices

contents: with strife.

contents.verseText: A wise servant will rule over a disgraceful son and share his inheritance as one of the brothers.
contents: A wise servant will rule over a disgraceful son
and share his inheritance as one of the brothers.

contents.verseText: A crucible for silver and a furnace for gold, but the LORD is the tester of hearts.
contents: A crucible for silver and a furnace for gold,
but the LORD is the tester of hearts.

contents.verseText: A wicked man listens to evil lips; a liar gives ear to a destructive tongue.
contents: A wicked man listens to evil lips;
a liar gives ear to a destructive tongue.

contents.verseText: He who mocks the poor insults their Maker; whoever gloats over calamity will not go unpunished.
contents: He who mocks the poor insults their Maker;
whoever gloats over calamity will not go unpunished.

contents.verseText: Grandchildren are the crown of the aged, and the glory of a son is his father.
contents: Grandchildren are the crown of the aged,
and the glory of a son is his father.

contents.verseText: Eloquent words are unfit for a fool; how much worse are lying lips to a ruler!
contents: Eloquent words are unfit for a fool;
how much worse are lying lips to a ruler!

contents.verseText: A bribe is a charm to its giver; wherever he turns, he succeeds.
contents: A bribe is a charm to its giver;
wherever he turns, he succeeds.

contents.verseText: Whoever conceals an offense promotes love, but he who brings it up separates friends.
contents: Whoever conceals an offense promotes love,
but he who brings it up separates friends.

contents.verseText: A rebuke cuts into a man of discernment deeper than a hundred lashes cut into a fool.
contents: A rebuke cuts into a man of discernment
deeper than a hundred lashes cut into a fool.

contents.verseText: An evil man seeks only rebellion; a cruel messenger will be sent against him.
contents: An evil man seeks only rebellion;
a cruel messenger will be sent against him.

contents.verseText: It is better to meet a bear robbed of her cubs than a fool in his folly.
contents: It is better to meet a bear robbed of her cubs
than a fool in his folly.

contents.verseText: If anyone returns evil for good, evil will never leave his house.
contents: If anyone returns evil for good,
evil will never leave his house.

contents.verseText: To start a quarrel is to release a flood; so abandon the dispute before it breaks out.
contents: To start a quarrel is to release a flood;
so abandon the dispute before it breaks out.

contents.verseText: Acquitting the guilty and condemning the righteous—both are detestable to the LORD.
contents: Acquitting the guilty and condemning the righteous—
both are detestable to the LORD.

contents.verseText: Why should the fool have money in his hand with no intention of buying wisdom?
contents: Why should the fool have money in his hand
with no intention of buying wisdom?

contents.verseText: A friend loves at all times, and a brother is born for adversity.
contents: A friend loves at all times,
and a brother is born for adversity.

contents.verseText: A man lacking judgment strikes hands in pledge and puts up security for his neighbor.
contents: A man lacking judgment strikes hands in pledge
and puts up security for his neighbor.

contents.verseText: He who loves transgression loves strife; he who builds his gate high invites destruction.
contents: He who loves transgression loves strife;
he who builds his gate high invites destruction.

contents.verseText: The one with a perverse heart finds no good, and he whose tongue is deceitful falls into trouble.
contents: The one with a perverse heart finds no good,
and he whose tongue is deceitful falls into trouble.

contents.verseText: A man fathers a fool to his own grief; the father of a fool has no joy.
contents: A man fathers a fool to his own grief;
the father of a fool has no joy.

contents.verseText: A joyful heart is good medicine, but a broken spirit dries up the bones.
contents: A joyful heart is good medicine,
but a broken spirit dries up the bones.

contents.verseText: A wicked man takes a covert bribe to subvert the course of justice.
contents: A wicked man takes a covert bribe

footnote.ft: Hebrew a bribe from the bosom

contents: to subvert the course of justice.

contents.verseText: Wisdom is the focus of the discerning, but the eyes of a fool wander to the ends of the earth.
contents: Wisdom is the focus of the discerning,
but the eyes of a fool wander to the ends of the earth.

contents.verseText: A foolish son brings grief to his father and bitterness to her who bore him.
contents: A foolish son brings grief to his father
and bitterness to her who bore him.

contents.verseText: It is surely not good to punish the innocent or to flog a noble for his honesty.
contents: It is surely not good to punish the innocent
or to flog a noble for his honesty.

contents.verseText: A man of knowledge restrains his words, and a man of understanding maintains a calm spirit.
contents: A man of knowledge restrains his words,
and a man of understanding maintains a calm spirit.

contents.verseText: Even a fool is considered wise if he keeps silent, and discerning when he holds his tongue.
contents: Even a fool is considered wise if he keeps silent,
and discerning when he holds his tongue.

contents.verseText: He who isolates himself pursues selfish desires; he rebels against all sound judgment.
contents: He who isolates himself pursues selfish desires;
he rebels against all sound judgment.

contents.verseText: A fool does not delight in understanding, but only in airing his opinions.
contents: A fool does not delight in understanding,
but only in airing his opinions.

contents.verseText: With a wicked man comes contempt as well, and shame is accompanied by disgrace.
contents: With a wicked man comes contempt as well,
and shame is accompanied by disgrace.

contents.verseText: The words of a man’s mouth are deep waters; the fountain of wisdom is a bubbling brook.
contents: The words of a man’s mouth are deep waters;
the fountain of wisdom is a bubbling brook.

contents.verseText: Showing partiality to the wicked is not good, nor is depriving the innocent of justice.
contents: Showing partiality

footnote.ft: Hebrew Lifting the face

contents: to the wicked is not good,
nor is depriving the innocent of justice.

contents.verseText: A fool’s lips bring him strife, and his mouth invites a beating.
contents: A fool’s lips bring him strife,
and his mouth invites a beating.

contents.verseText: A fool’s mouth is his ruin, and his lips are a snare to his soul.
contents: A fool’s mouth is his ruin,
and his lips are a snare to his soul.

contents.verseText: The words of a gossip are like choice morsels that go down into the inmost being.
contents: The words of a gossip are like choice morsels
that go down into the inmost being.

contents.verseText: Whoever is slothful in his work is brother to him who destroys.
contents: Whoever is slothful in his work
is brother to him who destroys.

contents.verseText: The name of the LORD is a strong tower; the righteous run to it and are safe.
contents: The name of the LORD is a strong tower;
the righteous run to it

footnote.ft: Or to Him

contents: and are safe.

contents.verseText: A rich man’s wealth is his fortified city; it is like a high wall in his imagination.
contents: A rich man’s wealth is his fortified city;
it is like a high wall in his imagination.

contents.verseText: Before his downfall a man’s heart is proud, but humility comes before honor.
contents: Before his downfall a man’s heart is proud,
but humility comes before honor.

contents.verseText: He who answers a matter before he hears it—this is folly and disgrace to him.
contents: He who answers a matter before he hears it—
this is folly and disgrace to him.

contents.verseText: The spirit of a man can endure his sickness, but who can survive a broken spirit?
contents: The spirit of a man can endure his sickness,
but who can survive a broken spirit?

contents.verseText: The heart of the discerning acquires knowledge, and the ear of the wise seeks it out.
contents: The heart of the discerning acquires knowledge,
and the ear of the wise seeks it out.

contents.verseText: A man’s gift opens doors for him, and brings him before great men.
contents: A man’s gift opens doors for him,
and brings him before great men.

contents.verseText: The first to state his case seems right until another comes and cross-examines him.
contents: The first to state his case seems right
until another comes and cross-examines him.

contents.verseText: Casting the lot ends quarrels and separates strong opponents.
contents: Casting the lot ends quarrels
and separates strong opponents.

contents.verseText: An offended brother is harder to win than a fortified city, and disputes are like the bars of a castle.
contents: An offended brother is harder to win than a fortified city,
and disputes are like the bars of a castle.

contents.verseText: From the fruit of his mouth a man’s belly is filled; with the harvest from his lips he is satisfied.
contents: From the fruit of his mouth a man’s belly is filled;
with the harvest from his lips he is satisfied.

contents.verseText: Life and death are in the power of the tongue, and those who love it will eat its fruit.
contents: Life and death are in the power of the tongue,
and those who love it will eat its fruit.

contents.verseText: He who finds a wife finds a good thing and obtains favor from the LORD.
contents: He who finds a wife finds a good thing
and obtains favor from the LORD.

contents.verseText: The poor man pleads for mercy, but the rich man answers harshly.
contents: The poor man pleads for mercy,
but the rich man answers harshly.

contents.verseText: A man of many companions may come to ruin, but there is a friend who stays closer than a brother.
contents: A man of many companions may come to ruin,
but there is a friend who stays closer than a brother.

contents.verseText: Better a poor man who walks with integrity than a fool whose lips are perverse.
contents: Better a poor man who walks with integrity
than a fool whose lips are perverse.

contents.verseText: Even zeal is no good without knowledge, and he who hurries his footsteps misses the mark.
contents: Even zeal is no good without knowledge,
and he who hurries his footsteps misses the mark.

contents.verseText: A man’s own folly subverts his way, yet his heart rages against the LORD.
contents: A man’s own folly subverts his way,
yet his heart rages against the LORD.

contents.verseText: Wealth attracts many friends, but a poor man is deserted by his friend.
contents: Wealth attracts many friends,
but a poor man is deserted by his friend.

contents.verseText: A false witness will not go unpunished, and one who utters lies will not escape.
contents: A false witness will not go unpunished,
and one who utters lies will not escape.

contents.verseText: Many seek the favor of the prince, and everyone is a friend of the gift giver.
contents: Many seek the favor of the prince,
and everyone is a friend of the gift giver.

contents.verseText: All the brothers of a poor man hate him—how much more do his friends avoid him! He may pursue them with pleading, but they are nowhere to be found.
contents: All the brothers of a poor man hate him—
how much more do his friends avoid him!
He may pursue them with pleading,
but they are nowhere to be found.

contents.verseText: He who acquires wisdom loves himself; one who safeguards understanding will find success.
contents: He who acquires wisdom loves himself;
one who safeguards understanding will find success.

contents.verseText: A false witness will not go unpunished, and one who pours out lies will perish.
contents: A false witness will not go unpunished,
and one who pours out lies will perish.

contents.verseText: Luxury is unseemly for a fool—how much worse for a slave to rule over princes!
contents: Luxury is unseemly for a fool—
how much worse for a slave to rule over princes!

contents.verseText: A man’s insight gives him patience, and his virtue is to overlook an offense.
contents: A man’s insight gives him patience,
and his virtue is to overlook an offense.

contents.verseText: A king’s rage is like the roar of a lion, but his favor is like dew on the grass.
contents: A king’s rage is like the roar of a lion,
but his favor is like dew on the grass.

contents.verseText: A foolish son is his father’s ruin, and a quarrelsome wife is like a constant dripping.
contents: A foolish son is his father’s ruin,
and a quarrelsome wife is like a constant dripping.

contents.verseText: Houses and wealth are inherited from fathers, but a prudent wife is from the LORD.
contents: Houses and wealth are inherited from fathers,
but a prudent wife is from the LORD.

contents.verseText: Laziness brings on deep sleep, and an idle soul will suffer hunger.
contents: Laziness brings on deep sleep,
and an idle soul will suffer hunger.

contents.verseText: He who keeps a commandment preserves his soul, but he who is careless in his ways will die.
contents: He who keeps a commandment preserves his soul,
but he who is careless in his ways will die.

contents.verseText: Kindness to the poor is a loan to the LORD, and He will repay the lender.
contents: Kindness to the poor is a loan to the LORD,
and He will repay the lender.

contents.verseText: Discipline your son, for in that there is hope; do not be party to his death.
contents: Discipline your son, for in that there is hope;
do not be party to his death.

contents.verseText: A man of great anger must pay the penalty; if you rescue him, you will have to do so again.
contents: A man of great anger must pay the penalty;
if you rescue him, you will have to do so again.

contents.verseText: Listen to counsel and accept discipline, that you may be wise the rest of your days.
contents: Listen to counsel and accept discipline,
that you may be wise the rest of your days.

contents.verseText: Many plans are in a man’s heart, but the purpose of the LORD will prevail.
contents: Many plans are in a man’s heart,
but the purpose of the LORD will prevail.

contents.verseText: The desire of a man is loving devotion; better to be poor than a liar.
contents: The desire of a man is loving devotion;
better to be poor than a liar.

contents.verseText: The fear of the LORD leads to life, that one may rest content, without visitation from harm.
contents: The fear of the LORD leads to life,
that one may rest content, without visitation from harm.

contents.verseText: The slacker buries his hand in the dish; he will not even bring it back to his mouth.
contents: The slacker buries his hand in the dish;
he will not even bring it back to his mouth.

contents.verseText: Strike a mocker, and the simple will beware; rebuke the discerning man, and he will gain knowledge.
contents: Strike a mocker, and the simple will beware;
rebuke the discerning man, and he will gain knowledge.

contents.verseText: He who assaults his father or evicts his mother is a son who brings shame and disgrace.
contents: He who assaults his father or evicts his mother
is a son who brings shame and disgrace.

contents.verseText: If you cease to hear instruction, my son, you will stray from the words of knowledge.
contents: If you cease to hear instruction, my son,
you will stray from the words of knowledge.

contents.verseText: A corrupt witness mocks justice, and a wicked mouth swallows iniquity.
contents: A corrupt witness mocks justice,
and a wicked mouth swallows iniquity.

contents.verseText: Judgments are prepared for mockers, and beatings for the backs of fools.
contents: Judgments are prepared for mockers,
and beatings for the backs of fools.

contents.verseText: Wine is a mocker, strong drink is a brawler, and whoever is led astray by them is not wise.
contents: Wine is a mocker, strong drink is a brawler,
and whoever is led astray by them is not wise.

contents.verseText: The terror of a king is like the roar of a lion; whoever provokes him forfeits his own life.
contents: The terror of a king is like the roar of a lion;
whoever provokes him forfeits his own life.

footnote.ft: Literally sins against his own soul

contents.verseText: It is honorable for a man to resolve a dispute, but any fool will quarrel.
contents: It is honorable for a man to resolve a dispute,
but any fool will quarrel.

contents.verseText: The slacker does not plow in season; at harvest time he looks, but nothing is there.
contents: The slacker does not plow in season;
at harvest time he looks, but nothing is there.

contents.verseText: The intentions of a man’s heart are deep waters, but a man of understanding draws them out.
contents: The intentions of a man’s heart are deep waters,
but a man of understanding draws them out.

contents.verseText: Many a man proclaims his loving devotion, but who can find a trustworthy man?
contents: Many a man proclaims his loving devotion,
but who can find a trustworthy man?

contents.verseText: The righteous man walks with integrity; blessed are his children after him.
contents: The righteous man walks with integrity;
blessed are his children after him.

contents.verseText: A king who sits on a throne to judge sifts out all evil with his eyes.
contents: A king who sits on a throne to judge
sifts out all evil with his eyes.

contents.verseText: Who can say, “I have kept my heart pure; I am cleansed from my sin”?
contents: Who can say, “I have kept my heart pure;
I am cleansed from my sin”?

contents.verseText: Differing weights and unequal measures—both are detestable to the LORD.
contents: Differing weights and unequal measures

footnote.ft: Hebrew A stone and a stone, an ephah and an ephah

contents: both are detestable to the LORD.

contents.verseText: Even a young man is known by his actions—whether his conduct is pure and upright.
contents: Even a young man is known by his actions—
whether his conduct is pure and upright.

contents.verseText: Ears that hear and eyes that see—the LORD has made them both.
contents: Ears that hear and eyes that see—
the LORD has made them both.

contents.verseText: Do not love sleep, or you will grow poor; open your eyes, and you will have plenty of food.
contents: Do not love sleep, or you will grow poor;
open your eyes, and you will have plenty of food.

contents.verseText: “Worthless, worthless!” says the buyer, but on the way out, he gloats.
contents: “Worthless, worthless!” says the buyer,
but on the way out, he gloats.

contents.verseText: There is an abundance of gold and rubies, but lips of knowledge are a rare treasure.
contents: There is an abundance of gold and rubies,
but lips of knowledge are a rare treasure.

contents.verseText: Take the garment of the one who posts security for a stranger; get collateral if it is for a foreigner.
contents: Take the garment of the one who posts security for a stranger;
get collateral if it is for a foreigner.

footnote.ft: Or a wayward woman

contents.verseText: Food gained by fraud is sweet to a man, but later his mouth is full of gravel.
contents: Food gained by fraud is sweet to a man,
but later his mouth is full of gravel.

contents.verseText: Set plans by consultation, and wage war under sound guidance.
contents: Set plans by consultation,
and wage war under sound guidance.

contents.verseText: He who reveals secrets is a constant gossip; avoid the one who babbles with his lips.
contents: He who reveals secrets is a constant gossip;
avoid the one who babbles

footnote.ft: Or the one who is simple

contents: with his lips.

contents.verseText: Whoever curses his father or mother, his lamp will be extinguished in deepest darkness.
contents: Whoever curses his father or mother,
his lamp will be extinguished in deepest darkness.

contents.verseText: An inheritance gained quickly will not be blessed in the end.
contents: An inheritance gained quickly
will not be blessed in the end.

contents.verseText: Do not say, “I will avenge this evil!” Wait on the LORD, and He will save you.
contents: Do not say, “I will avenge this evil!”
Wait on the LORD, and He will save you.

contents.verseText: Unequal weights are detestable to the LORD, and dishonest scales are no good.
contents: Unequal weights are detestable to the LORD,
and dishonest scales are no good.

contents.verseText: A man’s steps are from the LORD, so how can anyone understand his own way?
contents: A man’s steps are from the LORD,
so how can anyone understand his own way?

contents.verseText: It is a trap for a man to dedicate something rashly, only later to reconsider his vows.
contents: It is a trap for a man to dedicate something rashly,
only later to reconsider his vows.

contents.verseText: A wise king separates out the wicked and drives the threshing wheel over them.
contents: A wise king separates out the wicked
and drives the threshing wheel over them.

contents.verseText: The spirit of a man is the lamp of the LORD, searching out his inmost being.
contents: The spirit

footnote.ft: Or breath or speech

contents: of a man is the lamp of the LORD,
searching out his inmost being.

contents.verseText: Loving devotion and faithfulness preserve a king; by these he maintains his throne.
contents: Loving devotion and faithfulness preserve a king;
by these he maintains his throne.

contents.verseText: The glory of young men is their strength, and gray hair is the splendor of the old.
contents: The glory of young men is their strength,
and gray hair is the splendor of the old.

contents.verseText: Lashes and wounds scour evil, and beatings cleanse the inmost parts.
contents: Lashes and wounds scour evil,
and beatings cleanse the inmost parts.

contents.verseText: The king’s heart is a waterway in the hand of the LORD; He directs it where He pleases.
contents: The king’s heart is a waterway in the hand of the LORD;
He directs it where He pleases.

contents.verseText: All a man’s ways seem right to him, but the LORD weighs the heart.
contents: All a man’s ways seem right to him,
but the LORD weighs the heart.

contents.verseText: To do righteousness and justice is more desirable to the LORD than sacrifice.
contents: To do righteousness and justice
is more desirable to the LORD than sacrifice.

contents.verseText: Haughty eyes and a proud heart—the guides of the wicked—are sin.
contents: Haughty eyes and a proud heart—
the guides of the wicked—are sin.

contents.verseText: The plans of the diligent bring plenty, as surely as haste leads to poverty.
contents: The plans of the diligent bring plenty,
as surely as haste leads to poverty.

contents.verseText: Making a fortune by a lying tongue is a vanishing mist, a deadly pursuit.
contents: Making a fortune by a lying tongue
is a vanishing mist, a deadly pursuit.

contents.verseText: The violence of the wicked will sweep them away because they refuse to do what is just.
contents: The violence of the wicked will sweep them away
because they refuse to do what is just.

contents.verseText: The way of a guilty man is crooked, but the conduct of the innocent is upright.
contents: The way of a guilty man is crooked,
but the conduct of the innocent is upright.

contents.verseText: Better to live on a corner of the roof than to share a house with a quarrelsome wife.
contents: Better to live on a corner of the roof
than to share a house with a quarrelsome wife.

contents.verseText: The soul of the wicked man craves evil; his neighbor finds no favor in his eyes.
contents: The soul of the wicked man craves evil;
his neighbor finds no favor in his eyes.

contents.verseText: When a mocker is punished, the simple gain wisdom; and when a wise man is instructed, he acquires knowledge.
contents: When a mocker is punished, the simple gain wisdom;
and when a wise man is instructed, he acquires knowledge.

contents.verseText: The Righteous One considers the house of the wicked and brings the wicked to ruin.
contents: The Righteous One

footnote.ft: Or The righteous one

contents: considers the house of the wicked
and brings the wicked to ruin.

contents.verseText: Whoever shuts his ears to the cry of the poor, he too shall cry out and receive no answer.
contents: Whoever shuts his ears to the cry of the poor,
he too shall cry out and receive no answer.

contents.verseText: A gift in secret soothes anger, and a covert bribe pacifies great wrath.
contents: A gift in secret soothes anger,
and a covert bribe

footnote.ft: Hebrew a bribe in the bosom

contents: pacifies great wrath.

contents.verseText: Justice executed is a joy to the righteous, but a terror to the workers of iniquity.
contents: Justice executed is a joy to the righteous,
but a terror to the workers of iniquity.

contents.verseText: The man who strays from the path of understanding will rest in the assembly of the dead.
contents: The man who strays from the path of understanding
will rest in the assembly of the dead.

contents.verseText: He who loves pleasure will become poor; the one who loves wine and oil will never be rich.
contents: He who loves pleasure will become poor;
the one who loves wine and oil will never be rich.

contents.verseText: The wicked become a ransom for the righteous, and the faithless for the upright.
contents: The wicked become a ransom for the righteous,
and the faithless for the upright.

contents.verseText: Better to live in the desert than with a contentious and ill-tempered wife.
contents: Better to live in the desert
than with a contentious and ill-tempered wife.

contents.verseText: Precious treasures and oil are in the dwelling of the wise, but a foolish man consumes them.
contents: Precious treasures and oil are in the dwelling of the wise,
but a foolish man consumes them.

contents.verseText: He who pursues righteousness and loving devotion finds life, righteousness, and honor.
contents: He who pursues righteousness and loving devotion
finds life, righteousness, and honor.

contents.verseText: A wise man scales the city of the mighty and pulls down the stronghold in which they trust.
contents: A wise man scales the city of the mighty
and pulls down the stronghold in which they trust.

contents.verseText: He who guards his mouth and tongue keeps his soul from distress.
contents: He who guards his mouth and tongue
keeps his soul from distress.

contents.verseText: Mocker is the name of the proud and arrogant man—of him who acts with excessive pride.
contents: Mocker is the name of the proud and arrogant man—
of him who acts with excessive pride.

contents.verseText: The craving of the slacker kills him because his hands refuse to work.
contents: The craving of the slacker kills him
because his hands refuse to work.

contents.verseText: All day long he covets more, but the righteous give without restraint.
contents: All day long he covets more,
but the righteous give without restraint.

contents.verseText: The sacrifice of the wicked is detestable—how much more so when brought with ill intent!
contents: The sacrifice of the wicked is detestable—
how much more so when brought with ill intent!

contents.verseText: A lying witness will perish, but the man who listens to truth will speak forever.
contents: A lying witness will perish,
but the man who listens to truth will speak forever.

contents.verseText: A wicked man hardens his face, but the upright man makes his way sure.
contents: A wicked man hardens his face,

footnote.ft: Or puts up a bold front

contents: but the upright man makes his way sure.

contents.verseText: There is no wisdom, no understanding, no counsel that can prevail against the LORD.
contents: There is no wisdom, no understanding, no counsel
that can prevail against the LORD.

contents.verseText: A horse is prepared for the day of battle, but victory is of the LORD.
contents: A horse is prepared for the day of battle,
but victory is of the LORD.

contents.verseText: A good name is more desirable than great riches; favor is better than silver and gold.
contents: A good name is more desirable than great riches;
favor is better than silver and gold.

contents.verseText: The rich and the poor have this in common: The LORD is Maker of them all.
contents: The rich and the poor have this in common:
The LORD is Maker of them all.

contents.verseText: The prudent see danger and take cover, but the simple keep going and suffer the consequences.
contents: The prudent see danger and take cover,
but the simple keep going and suffer the consequences.

contents.verseText: The rewards of humility and the fear of the LORD are wealth and honor and life.
contents: The rewards of humility and the fear of the LORD
are wealth and honor and life.

contents.verseText: Thorns and snares lie on the path of the perverse; he who guards his soul stays far from them.
contents: Thorns and snares lie on the path of the perverse;
he who guards his soul stays far from them.

contents.verseText: Train up a child in the way he should go, and when he is old he will not depart from it.
contents: Train up a child in the way he should go,
and when he is old he will not depart from it.

contents.verseText: The rich rule over the poor, and the borrower is slave to the lender.
contents: The rich rule over the poor,
and the borrower is slave to the lender.

contents.verseText: He who sows injustice will reap disaster, and the rod of his fury will be destroyed.
contents: He who sows injustice will reap disaster,
and the rod of his fury will be destroyed.

footnote.ft: LXX includes God blesses a cheerful and generous man, but foolish works will come to an end; see also 2 Corinthians 9:7.

contents.verseText: A generous man will be blessed, for he shares his bread with the poor.
contents: A generous man

footnote.ft: Literally He whose eye is good

contents: will be blessed,
for he shares his bread with the poor.

contents.verseText: Drive out the mocker, and conflict will depart; even quarreling and insults will cease.
contents: Drive out the mocker, and conflict will depart;
even quarreling and insults will cease.

contents.verseText: He who loves a pure heart and gracious lips will have the king for a friend.
contents: He who loves a pure heart and gracious lips
will have the king for a friend.

contents.verseText: The LORD’s eyes keep watch over knowledge, but He frustrates the words of the faithless.
contents: The LORD’s eyes keep watch over knowledge,
but He frustrates the words of the faithless.

contents.verseText: The slacker says, “There is a lion outside! I will be slain in the streets!”
contents: The slacker says, “There is a lion outside!
I will be slain in the streets!”

contents.verseText: The mouth of an adulteress is a deep pit; he who is under the wrath of the LORD will fall into it.
contents: The mouth of an adulteress is a deep pit;
he who is under the wrath of the LORD will fall into it.

contents.verseText: Foolishness is bound up in the heart of a child, but the rod of discipline drives it far from him.
contents: Foolishness is bound up in the heart of a child,
but the rod of discipline drives it far from him.

contents.verseText: Oppressing the poor to enrich oneself or giving gifts to the rich will surely lead to poverty.
contents: Oppressing the poor to enrich oneself or giving gifts to the rich
will surely lead to poverty.

contents.verseText: Incline your ear and hear the words of the wise—apply your mind to my knowledge—
contents: Incline your ear and hear the words of the wise—
apply your mind to my knowledge—

contents.verseText: for it is pleasing when you keep them within you and they are constantly on your lips.
contents: for it is pleasing when you keep them within you
and they are constantly on your lips.

contents.verseText: So that your trust may be in the LORD, I instruct you today—yes, you.
contents: So that your trust may be in the LORD,
I instruct you today—yes, you.

contents.verseText: Have I not written for you thirty sayings about counsel and knowledge,
contents: Have I not written for you thirty sayings

footnote.ft: Or written for you excellent sayings or written for you three times

contents: about counsel and knowledge,

contents.verseText: to show you true and reliable words, that you may soundly answer those who sent you?
contents: to show you true and reliable words,
that you may soundly answer those who sent you?

contents.verseText: Do not rob a poor man because he is poor, and do not crush the afflicted at the gate,
contents: Do not rob a poor man because he is poor,
and do not crush the afflicted at the gate,

contents.verseText: for the LORD will take up their case and will plunder those who rob them.
contents: for the LORD will take up their case
and will plunder those who rob them.

contents.verseText: Do not make friends with an angry man, and do not associate with a hot-tempered man,
contents: Do not make friends with an angry man,
and do not associate with a hot-tempered man,

contents.verseText: or you may learn his ways and entangle yourself in a snare.
contents: or you may learn his ways
and entangle yourself in a snare.

contents.verseText: Do not be one who gives pledges, who puts up security for debts.
contents: Do not be one who gives pledges,
who puts up security for debts.

contents.verseText: If you have nothing with which to pay, why should your bed be taken from under you?
contents: If you have nothing with which to pay,
why should your bed be taken from under you?

contents.verseText: Do not move an ancient boundary stone which your fathers have placed.
contents: Do not move an ancient boundary stone
which your fathers have placed.

contents.verseText: Do you see a man skilled in his work? He will be stationed in the presence of kings; he will not stand before obscure men.
contents: Do you see a man skilled in his work?
He will be stationed in the presence of kings;
he will not stand before obscure men.

contents.verseText: When you sit down to dine with a ruler, consider carefully what is set before you,
contents: When you sit down to dine with a ruler,
consider carefully what is set before you,

footnote.ft: Or who is before you

contents.verseText: and put a knife to your throat if you possess a great appetite.
contents: and put a knife to your throat
if you possess a great appetite.

contents.verseText: Do not crave his delicacies, for that food is deceptive.
contents: Do not crave his delicacies,
for that food is deceptive.

contents.verseText: Do not wear yourself out to get rich; be wise enough to restrain yourself.
contents: Do not wear yourself out to get rich;
be wise enough to restrain yourself.

contents.verseText: When you glance at wealth, it disappears, for it makes wings for itself and flies like an eagle to the sky.
contents: When you glance at wealth, it disappears,
for it makes wings for itself
and flies like an eagle to the sky.

contents.verseText: Do not eat the bread of a stingy man, and do not crave his delicacies;
contents: Do not eat the bread of a stingy man,

footnote.ft: Literally of him whose eye is evil

contents: and do not crave his delicacies;

contents.verseText: for he is keeping track, inwardly counting the cost. “Eat and drink,” he says to you, but his heart is not with you.
contents: for he is keeping track,
inwardly counting the cost.

footnote.ft: Or for as he calculates in his soul, so is he

contents: “Eat and drink,” he says to you,
but his heart is not with you.

contents.verseText: You will vomit up what little you have eaten and waste your pleasant words.
contents: You will vomit up what little you have eaten
and waste your pleasant words.

contents.verseText: Do not speak to a fool, for he will despise the wisdom of your words.
contents: Do not speak to a fool,
for he will despise the wisdom of your words.

contents.verseText: Do not move an ancient boundary stone or encroach on the fields of the fatherless,
contents: Do not move an ancient boundary stone
or encroach on the fields of the fatherless,

contents.verseText: for their Redeemer is strong; He will take up their case against you.
contents: for their Redeemer is strong;
He will take up their case against you.

contents.verseText: Apply your heart to instruction and your ears to words of knowledge.
contents: Apply your heart to instruction
and your ears to words of knowledge.

contents.verseText: Do not withhold discipline from a child; although you strike him with a rod, he will not die.
contents: Do not withhold discipline from a child;
although you strike him with a rod, he will not die.

contents.verseText: Strike him with a rod, and you will deliver his soul from Sheol.
contents: Strike him with a rod,
and you will deliver his soul from Sheol.

contents.verseText: My son, if your heart is wise, my own heart will indeed rejoice.
contents: My son, if your heart is wise,
my own heart will indeed rejoice.

contents.verseText: My inmost being will rejoice when your lips speak what is right.
contents: My inmost being

footnote.ft: Hebrew My kidneys

contents: will rejoice
when your lips speak what is right.

contents.verseText: Do not let your heart envy sinners, but always continue in the fear of the LORD.
contents: Do not let your heart envy sinners,
but always continue in the fear of the LORD.

contents.verseText: For surely there is a future, and your hope will not be cut off.
contents: For surely there is a future,
and your hope will not be cut off.

contents.verseText: Listen, my son, and be wise, and guide your heart on the right course.
contents: Listen, my son, and be wise,
and guide your heart on the right course.

contents.verseText: Do not join those who drink too much wine or gorge themselves on meat.
contents: Do not join those who drink too much wine
or gorge themselves on meat.

contents.verseText: For the drunkard and the glutton will come to poverty, and drowsiness will clothe them in rags.
contents: For the drunkard and the glutton will come to poverty,
and drowsiness will clothe them in rags.

contents.verseText: Listen to your father who gave you life, and do not despise your mother when she is old.
contents: Listen to your father who gave you life,
and do not despise your mother when she is old.

contents.verseText: Invest in truth and never sell it—in wisdom and instruction and understanding.
contents: Invest in truth and never sell it—
in wisdom and instruction and understanding.

contents.verseText: The father of a righteous man will greatly rejoice, and he who fathers a wise son will delight in him.
contents: The father of a righteous man will greatly rejoice,
and he who fathers a wise son will delight in him.

contents.verseText: May your father and mother be glad, and may she who gave you birth rejoice!
contents: May your father and mother be glad,
and may she who gave you birth rejoice!

contents.verseText: My son, give me your heart, and let your eyes delight in my ways.
contents: My son, give me your heart,
and let your eyes delight in my ways.

contents.verseText: For a prostitute is a deep pit, and an adulteress is a narrow well.
contents: For a prostitute is a deep pit,
and an adulteress

footnote.ft: Or a foreign woman or a wayward wife

contents: is a narrow well.

contents.verseText: Like a robber she lies in wait and multiplies the faithless among men.
contents: Like a robber she lies in wait
and multiplies the faithless among men.

contents.verseText: Who has woe? Who has sorrow? Who has contentions? Who has complaints? Who has needless wounds? Who has bloodshot eyes?
contents: Who has woe? Who has sorrow?
Who has contentions? Who has complaints?
Who has needless wounds? Who has bloodshot eyes?

contents.verseText: Those who linger over wine, who go to taste mixed drinks.
contents: Those who linger over wine,
who go to taste mixed drinks.

contents.verseText: Do not gaze at wine while it is red, when it sparkles in the cup and goes down smoothly.
contents: Do not gaze at wine while it is red,
when it sparkles in the cup
and goes down smoothly.

contents.verseText: In the end it bites like a snake and stings like a viper.
contents: In the end it bites like a snake
and stings like a viper.

contents.verseText: Your eyes will see strange things, and your mind will utter perversities.
contents: Your eyes will see strange things,
and your mind will utter perversities.

contents.verseText: You will be like one sleeping on the high seas or lying on the top of a mast:
contents: You will be like one sleeping on the high seas
or lying on the top of a mast:

contents.verseText: “They struck me, but I feel no pain! They beat me, but I did not know it! When can I wake up to search for another drink?”
contents: “They struck me, but I feel no pain!
They beat me, but I did not know it!
When can I wake up
to search for another drink?”

contents.verseText: Do not envy wicked men or desire their company;
contents: Do not envy wicked men
or desire their company;

contents.verseText: for their hearts devise violence, and their lips declare trouble.
contents: for their hearts devise violence,
and their lips declare trouble.

contents.verseText: By wisdom a house is built and by understanding it is established;
contents: By wisdom a house is built
and by understanding it is established;

contents.verseText: through knowledge its rooms are filled with every precious and beautiful treasure.
contents: through knowledge its rooms are filled
with every precious and beautiful treasure.

contents.verseText: A wise man is strong, and a man of knowledge enhances his strength.
contents: A wise man is strong,

footnote.ft: LXX The wise are mightier than the strong

contents: and a man of knowledge enhances his strength.

contents.verseText: Only with sound guidance should you wage war, and victory lies in a multitude of counselors.
contents: Only with sound guidance should you wage war,
and victory lies in a multitude of counselors.

contents.verseText: Wisdom is too high for a fool; he does not open his mouth in the meeting place.
contents: Wisdom is too high for a fool;
he does not open his mouth in the meeting place.

contents.verseText: He who plots evil will be called a schemer.
contents: He who plots evil
will be called a schemer.

contents.verseText: A foolish scheme is sin, and a mocker is detestable to men.
contents: A foolish scheme is sin,
and a mocker is detestable to men.

contents.verseText: If you faint in the day of distress, how small is your strength!
contents: If you faint in the day of distress,
how small is your strength!

contents.verseText: Rescue those being led away to death, and restrain those stumbling toward the slaughter.
contents: Rescue those being led away to death,
and restrain those stumbling toward the slaughter.

contents.verseText: If you say, “Behold, we did not know about this,” does not He who weighs hearts consider it? Does not the One who guards your life know? Will He not repay a man according to his deeds?
contents: If you say, “Behold, we did not know about this,”
does not He who weighs hearts consider it?
Does not the One who guards your life know?
Will He not repay a man according to his deeds?

contents.verseText: Eat honey, my son, for it is good, and the honeycomb is sweet to your taste.
contents: Eat honey, my son, for it is good,
and the honeycomb is sweet to your taste.

contents.verseText: Know therefore that wisdom is sweet to your soul. If you find it, there is a future for you, and your hope will never be cut off.
contents: Know therefore that wisdom is sweet to your soul.
If you find it, there is a future for you,
and your hope will never be cut off.

contents.verseText: Do not lie in wait, O wicked man, near the dwelling of the righteous; do not destroy his resting place.
contents: Do not lie in wait, O wicked man, near the dwelling of the righteous;
do not destroy his resting place.

contents.verseText: For though a righteous man may fall seven times, he still gets up; but the wicked stumble in bad times.
contents: For though a righteous man may fall seven times, he still gets up;
but the wicked stumble in bad times.

contents.verseText: Do not gloat when your enemy falls, and do not let your heart rejoice when he stumbles,
contents: Do not gloat when your enemy falls,
and do not let your heart rejoice when he stumbles,

contents.verseText: or the LORD will see and disapprove, and turn His wrath away from him.
contents: or the LORD will see and disapprove,
and turn His wrath away from him.

contents.verseText: Do not fret over evildoers, and do not be envious of the wicked.
contents: Do not fret over evildoers,
and do not be envious of the wicked.

contents.verseText: For the evil man has no future; the lamp of the wicked will be extinguished.
contents: For the evil man has no future;
the lamp of the wicked will be extinguished.

contents.verseText: My son, fear the LORD and the king, and do not associate with the rebellious.
contents: My son, fear the LORD and the king,
and do not associate with the rebellious.

contents.verseText: For they will bring sudden destruction. Who knows what ruin they can bring?
contents: For they will bring sudden destruction.
Who knows what ruin they can bring?

contents.verseText: These also are sayings of the wise: To show partiality in judgment is not good.
contents: These also are sayings of the wise:
To show partiality in judgment
is not good.

contents.verseText: Whoever tells the guilty, “You are innocent”—peoples will curse him, and nations will denounce him;
contents: Whoever tells the guilty, “You are innocent”—
peoples will curse him, and nations will denounce him;

contents.verseText: but it will go well with those who convict the guilty, and rich blessing will come upon them.
contents: but it will go well with those who convict the guilty,
and rich blessing will come upon them.

contents.verseText: An honest answer given is like a kiss on the lips.
contents: An honest answer given
is like a kiss on the lips.

contents.verseText: Complete your outdoor work and prepare your field; after that, you may build your house.
contents: Complete your outdoor work and prepare your field;
after that, you may build your house.

contents.verseText: Do not testify against your neighbor without cause, and do not deceive with your lips.
contents: Do not testify against your neighbor without cause,
and do not deceive with your lips.

contents.verseText: Do not say, “I will do to him as he has done to me; I will repay the man according to his work.”
contents: Do not say, “I will do to him as he has done to me;
I will repay the man according to his work.”

contents.verseText: I went past the field of a slacker and by the vineyard of a man lacking judgment.
contents: I went past the field of a slacker
and by the vineyard of a man lacking judgment.

contents.verseText: Thorns had grown up everywhere, thistles had covered the ground, and the stone wall was broken down.
contents: Thorns had grown up everywhere,
thistles had covered the ground,
and the stone wall was broken down.

contents.verseText: I observed and took it to heart; I looked and received instruction:
contents: I observed and took it to heart;
I looked and received instruction:

contents.verseText: A little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the hands to rest,
contents: A little sleep, a little slumber,
a little folding of the hands to rest,

contents.verseText: and poverty will come upon you like a robber, and need like a bandit.
contents: and poverty will come upon you like a robber,
and need like a bandit.

contents.verseText: These are additional proverbs of Solomon, which were copied by the men of Hezekiah king of Judah:
contents: These are additional proverbs of Solomon, which were copied by the men of Hezekiah king of Judah:

contents.verseText: It is the glory of God to conceal a matter and the glory of kings to search it out.
contents: It is the glory of God to conceal a matter
and the glory of kings to search it out.

contents.verseText: As the heavens are high and the earth is deep, so the hearts of kings cannot be searched.
contents: As the heavens are high and the earth is deep,
so the hearts of kings cannot be searched.

contents.verseText: Remove the dross from the silver, and a vessel for a silversmith will come forth.
contents: Remove the dross from the silver,
and a vessel for a silversmith will come forth.

contents.verseText: Remove the wicked from the king’s presence, and his throne will be established in righteousness.
contents: Remove the wicked from the king’s presence,
and his throne will be established in righteousness.

contents.verseText: Do not exalt yourself in the presence of the king, and do not stand in the place of great men;
contents: Do not exalt yourself in the presence of the king,
and do not stand in the place of great men;

contents.verseText: for it is better that he says to you, “Come up here!” than that you should be demoted in the presence of the prince. Even what you have seen with your own eyes,
contents: for it is better that he says to you, “Come up here!”
than that you should be demoted in the presence of the prince.
Even what

footnote.ft: Or Even the one

contents: you have seen with your own eyes,

contents.verseText: do not bring hastily to court. Otherwise, what will you do in the end when your neighbor puts you to shame?
contents: do not bring hastily to court.
Otherwise, what will you do in the end
when your neighbor puts you to shame?

contents.verseText: Argue your case with your neighbor without betraying another’s confidence,
contents: Argue your case with your neighbor
without betraying another’s confidence,

contents.verseText: lest the one who hears may disgrace you, and your infamy never go away.
contents: lest the one who hears may disgrace you,
and your infamy never go away.

contents.verseText: A word fitly spoken is like apples of gold in settings of silver.
contents: A word fitly spoken
is like apples of gold in settings of silver.

contents.verseText: Like an earring of gold or an ornament of fine gold is a wise man’s rebuke to a listening ear.
contents: Like an earring of gold or an ornament of fine gold
is a wise man’s rebuke to a listening ear.

contents.verseText: Like the cold of snow in the time of harvest is a trustworthy messenger to those who send him; he refreshes the soul of his masters.
contents: Like the cold of snow in the time of harvest
is a trustworthy messenger to those who send him;
he refreshes the soul of his masters.

contents.verseText: Like clouds and wind without rain is the man who boasts of gifts never given.
contents: Like clouds and wind without rain
is the man who boasts of gifts never given.

contents.verseText: Through patience a ruler can be persuaded, and a gentle tongue can break a bone.
contents: Through patience a ruler can be persuaded,
and a gentle tongue can break a bone.

contents.verseText: If you find honey, eat just what you need, lest you have too much and vomit it up.
contents: If you find honey, eat just what you need,
lest you have too much and vomit it up.

contents.verseText: Seldom set foot in your neighbor’s house, lest he grow weary and hate you.
contents: Seldom set foot in your neighbor’s house,
lest he grow weary and hate you.

contents.verseText: Like a club or sword or sharp arrow is a man who bears false witness against his neighbor.
contents: Like a club or sword or sharp arrow
is a man who bears false witness against his neighbor.

contents.verseText: Like a broken tooth or a foot out of joint is confidence in a faithless man in time of trouble.
contents: Like a broken tooth or a foot out of joint
is confidence in a faithless man in time of trouble.

contents.verseText: Like one who removes a garment on a cold day or vinegar poured on a wound is one who sings songs to a heavy heart.
contents: Like one who removes a garment on a cold day
or vinegar poured on a wound

footnote.ft: Or on soda

contents: is one who sings songs to a heavy heart.

contents.verseText: If your enemy is hungry, give him food to eat, and if he is thirsty, give him water to drink.
contents: If your enemy is hungry, give him food to eat,
and if he is thirsty, give him water to drink.

contents.verseText: For in so doing, you will heap burning coals on his head, and the LORD will reward you.
contents: For in so doing, you will heap burning coals on his head,

footnote.ft: LXX; Hebrew For you will heap burning coals on his head; cited in Romans 12:20

contents: and the LORD will reward you.

contents.verseText: As the north wind brings forth rain, so a backbiting tongue brings angry looks.
contents: As the north wind brings forth rain,
so a backbiting tongue brings angry looks.

contents.verseText: Better to live on a corner of the roof than to share a house with a quarrelsome wife.
contents: Better to live on a corner of the roof
than to share a house with a quarrelsome wife.

contents.verseText: Like cold water to a weary soul is good news from a distant land.
contents: Like cold water to a weary soul
is good news from a distant land.

contents.verseText: Like a muddied spring or a polluted well is a righteous man who gives way to the wicked.
contents: Like a muddied spring or a polluted well
is a righteous man who gives way to the wicked.

contents.verseText: It is not good to eat too much honey or to search out one’s own glory.
contents: It is not good to eat too much honey
or to search out one’s own glory.

contents.verseText: Like a city whose walls are broken down is a man who does not control his temper.
contents: Like a city whose walls are broken down
is a man who does not control his temper.

contents.verseText: Like snow in summer and rain at harvest, honor does not befit a fool.
contents: Like snow in summer and rain at harvest,
honor does not befit a fool.

contents.verseText: Like a fluttering sparrow or darting swallow, an undeserved curse does not come to rest.
contents: Like a fluttering sparrow or darting swallow,
an undeserved curse does not come to rest.

contents.verseText: A whip for the horse, a bridle for the donkey, and a rod for the backs of fools!
contents: A whip for the horse, a bridle for the donkey,
and a rod for the backs of fools!

contents.verseText: Do not answer a fool according to his folly, or you yourself will be like him.
contents: Do not answer a fool according to his folly,
or you yourself will be like him.

contents.verseText: Answer a fool according to his folly, lest he become wise in his own eyes.
contents: Answer a fool according to his folly,
lest he become wise in his own eyes.

contents.verseText: Like cutting off one’s own feet or drinking violence is the sending of a message by the hand of a fool.
contents: Like cutting off one’s own feet or drinking violence
is the sending of a message by the hand of a fool.

contents.verseText: Like lame legs hanging limp is a proverb in the mouth of a fool.
contents: Like lame legs hanging limp
is a proverb in the mouth of a fool.

contents.verseText: Like binding a stone into a sling is the giving of honor to a fool.
contents: Like binding a stone into a sling
is the giving of honor to a fool.

contents.verseText: Like a thorn that falls into the hand of a drunkard is a proverb in the mouth of a fool.
contents: Like a thorn that falls into the hand of a drunkard
is a proverb in the mouth of a fool.

contents.verseText: Like an archer who wounds at random is he who hires a fool or passerby.
contents: Like an archer who wounds at random
is he who hires a fool or passerby.

contents.verseText: As a dog returns to its vomit, so a fool repeats his folly.
contents: As a dog returns to its vomit,

footnote.ft: Cited in 2 Peter 2:22

contents: so a fool repeats his folly.

contents.verseText: Do you see a man who is wise in his own eyes? There is more hope for a fool than for him.
contents: Do you see a man who is wise in his own eyes?
There is more hope for a fool than for him.

contents.verseText: The slacker says, “A lion is in the road! A fierce lion roams the public square!”
contents: The slacker says, “A lion is in the road!
A fierce lion roams the public square!”

contents.verseText: As a door turns on its hinges, so the slacker turns on his bed.
contents: As a door turns on its hinges,
so the slacker turns on his bed.

contents.verseText: The slacker buries his hand in the dish; it wearies him to bring it back to his mouth.
contents: The slacker buries his hand in the dish;
it wearies him to bring it back to his mouth.

contents.verseText: The slacker is wiser in his own eyes than seven men who answer discreetly.
contents: The slacker is wiser in his own eyes
than seven men who answer discreetly.

contents.verseText: Like one who grabs a dog by the ears is a passerby who meddles in a quarrel not his own.
contents: Like one who grabs a dog by the ears
is a passerby who meddles in a quarrel not his own.

contents.verseText: Like a madman shooting firebrands and deadly arrows,
contents: Like a madman shooting firebrands
and deadly arrows,

contents.verseText: so is the man who deceives his neighbor and says, “I was only joking!”
contents: so is the man who deceives his neighbor
and says, “I was only joking!”

contents.verseText: Without wood, a fire goes out; without gossip, a conflict ceases.
contents: Without wood, a fire goes out;
without gossip, a conflict ceases.

contents.verseText: Like charcoal for embers and wood for fire, so is a quarrelsome man for kindling strife.
contents: Like charcoal for embers and wood for fire,
so is a quarrelsome man for kindling strife.

contents.verseText: The words of a gossip are like choice morsels that go down into the inmost being.
contents: The words of a gossip are like choice morsels
that go down into the inmost being.

contents.verseText: Like glaze covering an earthen vessel are burning lips and a wicked heart.
contents: Like glaze covering an earthen vessel
are burning

footnote.ft: Hebrew; LXX smooth

contents: lips and a wicked heart.

contents.verseText: A hateful man disguises himself with his speech, but he lays up deceit in his heart.
contents: A hateful man disguises himself with his speech,
but he lays up deceit in his heart.

contents.verseText: When he speaks graciously, do not believe him, for seven abominations fill his heart.
contents: When he speaks graciously, do not believe him,
for seven abominations fill his heart.

contents.verseText: Though his hatred is concealed by deception, his wickedness will be exposed in the assembly.
contents: Though his hatred is concealed by deception,
his wickedness will be exposed in the assembly.

contents.verseText: He who digs a pit will fall into it, and he who rolls a stone will have it roll back on him.
contents: He who digs a pit will fall into it,
and he who rolls a stone will have it roll back on him.

contents.verseText: A lying tongue hates those it crushes, and a flattering mouth causes ruin.
contents: A lying tongue hates those it crushes,
and a flattering mouth causes ruin.

contents.verseText: Do not boast about tomorrow, for you do not know what a day may bring.
contents: Do not boast about tomorrow,
for you do not know what a day may bring.

contents.verseText: Let another praise you, and not your own mouth—a stranger, and not your own lips.
contents: Let another praise you, and not your own mouth—
a stranger, and not your own lips.

contents.verseText: A stone is heavy and sand is a burden, but aggravation from a fool outweighs them both.
contents: A stone is heavy and sand is a burden,
but aggravation from a fool outweighs them both.

contents.verseText: Wrath is cruel and anger is like a flood, but who can withstand jealousy?
contents: Wrath is cruel and anger is like a flood,
but who can withstand jealousy?

contents.verseText: Better an open rebuke than love that is concealed.
contents: Better an open rebuke
than love that is concealed.

contents.verseText: The wounds of a friend are faithful, but the kisses of an enemy are deceitful.
contents: The wounds of a friend are faithful,
but the kisses of an enemy are deceitful.

contents.verseText: The soul that is full loathes honey, but to a hungry soul, any bitter thing is sweet.
contents: The soul that is full loathes honey,
but to a hungry soul, any bitter thing is sweet.

contents.verseText: Like a bird that strays from its nest is a man who wanders from his home.
contents: Like a bird that strays from its nest
is a man who wanders from his home.

contents.verseText: Oil and incense bring joy to the heart, and the sweetness of a friend is counsel to the soul.
contents: Oil and incense bring joy to the heart,
and the sweetness of a friend is counsel to the soul.

contents.verseText: Do not forsake your friend or your father’s friend, and do not go to your brother’s house in the day of your calamity; better a neighbor nearby than a brother far away.
contents: Do not forsake your friend or your father’s friend,
and do not go to your brother’s house
in the day of your calamity;
better a neighbor nearby
than a brother far away.

contents.verseText: Be wise, my son, and bring joy to my heart, so that I can answer him who taunts me.
contents: Be wise, my son, and bring joy to my heart,
so that I can answer him who taunts me.

contents.verseText: The prudent see danger and take cover; but the simple keep going and pay the penalty.
contents: The prudent see danger and take cover;
but the simple keep going and pay the penalty.

contents.verseText: Take the garment of him who posts security for a stranger; get collateral if it is for a foreigner.
contents: Take the garment of him who posts security for a stranger;
get collateral if it is for a foreigner.

footnote.ft: Or a wayward woman

contents.verseText: If one blesses his neighbor with a loud voice early in the morning, it will be counted to him as a curse.
contents: If one blesses his neighbor with a loud voice early in the morning,
it will be counted to him as a curse.

contents.verseText: A constant dripping on a rainy day and a contentious woman are alike—
contents: A constant dripping on a rainy day
and a contentious woman are alike—

contents.verseText: restraining her is like holding back the wind or grasping oil with one’s right hand.
contents: restraining her is like holding back the wind
or grasping oil with one’s right hand.

contents.verseText: As iron sharpens iron, so one man sharpens another.
contents: As iron sharpens iron,
so one man sharpens another.

footnote.ft: Hebrew sharpens the face of another or sharpens the countenance of a friend

contents.verseText: Whoever tends a fig tree will eat its fruit, and he who looks after his master will be honored.
contents: Whoever tends a fig tree will eat its fruit,
and he who looks after his master will be honored.

contents.verseText: As water reflects the face, so the heart reflects the true man.
contents: As water reflects the face,
so the heart reflects the true man.

contents.verseText: Sheol and Abaddon are never satisfied; so the eyes of man are never satisfied.
contents: Sheol and Abaddon

footnote.ft: Or Death and Destruction

contents: are never satisfied;
so the eyes of man are never satisfied.

contents.verseText: A crucible for silver and a furnace for gold, but a man is tested by the praise accorded him.
contents: A crucible for silver and a furnace for gold,
but a man is tested by the praise accorded him.

contents.verseText: Though you grind a fool like grain with mortar and a pestle, yet his folly will not depart from him.
contents: Though you grind a fool like grain with mortar and a pestle,
yet his folly will not depart from him.

contents.verseText: Be sure to know the state of your flocks, and pay close attention to your herds;
contents: Be sure to know the state of your flocks,
and pay close attention to your herds;

contents.verseText: for riches are not forever, nor does a crown endure to every generation.
contents: for riches are not forever,
nor does a crown endure to every generation.

contents.verseText: When hay is removed and new growth appears and the grain from the hills is gathered,
contents: When hay is removed and new growth appears
and the grain from the hills is gathered,

contents.verseText: the lambs will provide you with clothing, and the goats with the price of a field.
contents: the lambs will provide you with clothing,
and the goats with the price of a field.

contents.verseText: You will have plenty of goats’ milk to feed you—food for your household and nourishment for your maidservants.
contents: You will have plenty of goats’ milk to feed you—
food for your household
and nourishment for your maidservants.

contents.verseText: The wicked flee when no one pursues, but the righteous are as bold as a lion.
contents: The wicked flee when no one pursues,
but the righteous are as bold as a lion.

contents.verseText: A land in rebellion has many rulers, but a man of understanding and knowledge maintains order.
contents: A land in rebellion has many rulers,
but a man of understanding and knowledge maintains order.

contents.verseText: A destitute leader who oppresses the poor is like a driving rain that leaves no food.
contents: A destitute leader who oppresses the poor
is like a driving rain that leaves no food.

contents.verseText: Those who forsake the law praise the wicked, but those who keep the law resist them.
contents: Those who forsake the law praise the wicked,
but those who keep the law resist them.

contents.verseText: Evil men do not understand justice, but those who seek the LORD comprehend fully.
contents: Evil men do not understand justice,
but those who seek the LORD comprehend fully.

contents.verseText: Better a poor man who walks with integrity than a rich man whose ways are perverse.
contents: Better a poor man who walks with integrity
than a rich man whose ways are perverse.

contents.verseText: A discerning son keeps the law, but a companion of gluttons disgraces his father.
contents: A discerning son keeps the law,
but a companion of gluttons disgraces his father.

contents.verseText: He who increases his wealth by interest and usury lays it up for one who is kind to the poor.
