contents: He who increases his wealth by interest and usury
lays it up for one who is kind to the poor.

contents.verseText: Whoever turns his ear away from hearing the law, even his prayer is detestable.
contents: Whoever turns his ear away from hearing the law,
even his prayer is detestable.

contents.verseText: He who leads the upright along the path of evil will fall into his own pit, but the blameless will inherit what is good.
contents: He who leads the upright along the path of evil will fall into his own pit,
but the blameless will inherit what is good.

contents.verseText: A rich man is wise in his own eyes, but a poor man with discernment sees through him.
contents: A rich man is wise in his own eyes,
but a poor man with discernment sees through him.

contents.verseText: When the righteous triumph, there is great glory, but when the wicked rise, men hide themselves.
contents: When the righteous triumph, there is great glory,
but when the wicked rise, men hide themselves.

contents.verseText: He who conceals his sins will not prosper, but whoever confesses and renounces them will find mercy.
contents: He who conceals his sins will not prosper,
but whoever confesses and renounces them will find mercy.

contents.verseText: Blessed is the man who is always reverent, but he who hardens his heart falls into trouble.
contents: Blessed is the man who is always reverent,

footnote.ft: Or always fears the LORD; Hebrew does not include the LORD.

contents: but he who hardens his heart falls into trouble.

contents.verseText: Like a roaring lion or a charging bear is a wicked ruler over a helpless people.
contents: Like a roaring lion or a charging bear
is a wicked ruler over a helpless people.

contents.verseText: A leader who lacks judgment is also a great oppressor, but he who hates dishonest profit will prolong his days.
contents: A leader who lacks judgment is also a great oppressor,
but he who hates dishonest profit will prolong his days.

contents.verseText: A man burdened by bloodguilt will flee into the Pit; let no one support him.
contents: A man burdened by bloodguilt will flee into the Pit;

footnote.ft: Or will be a fugitive until death

contents: let no one support him.

contents.verseText: He who walks with integrity will be kept safe, but whoever is perverse in his ways will suddenly fall.
contents: He who walks with integrity will be kept safe,
but whoever is perverse in his ways will suddenly fall.

contents.verseText: The one who works his land will have plenty of food, but whoever chases fantasies will have his fill of poverty.
contents: The one who works his land will have plenty of food,
but whoever chases fantasies will have his fill of poverty.

contents.verseText: A faithful man will abound with blessings, but one eager to be rich will not go unpunished.
contents: A faithful man will abound with blessings,
but one eager to be rich will not go unpunished.

contents.verseText: To show partiality is not good, yet a man will do wrong for a piece of bread.
contents: To show partiality is not good,
yet a man will do wrong for a piece of bread.

contents.verseText: A stingy man hastens after wealth and does not know that poverty awaits him.
contents: A stingy man

footnote.ft: Hebrew A man whose eye is evil

contents: hastens after wealth
and does not know that poverty awaits him.

contents.verseText: He who rebukes a man will later find more favor than one who flatters with his tongue.
contents: He who rebukes a man will later find more favor
than one who flatters with his tongue.

contents.verseText: He who robs his father or mother, saying, “It is not wrong,” is a companion to the man who destroys.
contents: He who robs his father or mother, saying, “It is not wrong,”
is a companion to the man who destroys.

contents.verseText: A greedy man stirs up strife, but he who trusts in the LORD will prosper.
contents: A greedy man stirs up strife,
but he who trusts in the LORD will prosper.

contents.verseText: He who trusts in himself is a fool, but one who walks in wisdom will be safe.
contents: He who trusts in himself is a fool,
but one who walks in wisdom will be safe.

contents.verseText: Whoever gives to the poor will not be in need, but he who hides his eyes will receive many curses.
contents: Whoever gives to the poor will not be in need,
but he who hides his eyes will receive many curses.

contents.verseText: When the wicked come to power, people hide themselves; but when they perish, the righteous flourish.
contents: When the wicked come to power, people hide themselves;
but when they perish, the righteous flourish.

contents.verseText: A man who remains stiff-necked after much reproof will suddenly be shattered beyond recovery.
contents: A man who remains stiff-necked after much reproof
will suddenly be shattered beyond recovery.

contents.verseText: When the righteous flourish, the people rejoice, but when the wicked rule, the people groan.
contents: When the righteous flourish, the people rejoice,
but when the wicked rule, the people groan.

contents.verseText: A man who loves wisdom brings joy to his father, but a companion of prostitutes squanders his wealth.
contents: A man who loves wisdom brings joy to his father,
but a companion of prostitutes squanders his wealth.

contents.verseText: By justice a king brings stability to the land, but a man who exacts tribute demolishes it.
contents: By justice a king brings stability to the land,
but a man who exacts tribute

footnote.ft: Or who taxes heavily or who takes bribes

contents: demolishes it.

contents.verseText: A man who flatters his neighbor spreads a net for his feet.
contents: A man who flatters his neighbor
spreads a net for his feet.

contents.verseText: An evil man is caught by his own sin, but a righteous one sings and rejoices.
contents: An evil man is caught by his own sin,
but a righteous one sings and rejoices.

contents.verseText: The righteous consider the cause of the poor, but the wicked have no regard for such concerns.
contents: The righteous consider the cause of the poor,
but the wicked have no regard for such concerns.

contents.verseText: Mockers inflame a city, but the wise turn away anger.
contents: Mockers inflame a city,
but the wise turn away anger.

contents.verseText: If a wise man goes to court with a fool, there will be raving and laughing with no resolution.
contents: If a wise man goes to court with a fool,
there will be raving and laughing with no resolution.

contents.verseText: Men of bloodshed hate a blameless man, but the upright care for his life.
contents: Men of bloodshed hate a blameless man,
but the upright care for his life.

footnote.ft: Or but the upright seek his soul

contents.verseText: A fool vents all his anger, but a wise man holds it back.
contents: A fool vents all his anger,
but a wise man holds it back.

contents.verseText: If a ruler listens to lies, all his officials will be wicked.
contents: If a ruler listens to lies,
all his officials will be wicked.

contents.verseText: The poor man and the oppressor have this in common: The LORD gives light to the eyes of both.
contents: The poor man and the oppressor have this in common:
The LORD gives light to the eyes of both.

contents.verseText: A king who judges the poor with fairness—his throne will be established forever.
contents: A king who judges the poor with fairness—
his throne will be established forever.

contents.verseText: A rod of correction imparts wisdom, but a child left to himself disgraces his mother.
contents: A rod of correction imparts wisdom,
but a child left to himself disgraces his mother.

contents.verseText: When the wicked thrive, rebellion increases; but the righteous will see their downfall.
contents: When the wicked thrive, rebellion increases;
but the righteous will see their downfall.

contents.verseText: Discipline your son, and he will give you rest; he will bring delight to your soul.
contents: Discipline your son, and he will give you rest;
he will bring delight to your soul.

contents.verseText: Where there is no vision, the people cast off restraint; but blessed is he who keeps the Law.
contents: Where there is no vision, the people cast off restraint;
but blessed is he who keeps the Law.

contents.verseText: A servant cannot be corrected by words alone; though he understands, he will not respond.
contents: A servant cannot be corrected by words alone;
though he understands, he will not respond.

contents.verseText: Do you see a man who speaks in haste? There is more hope for a fool than for him.
contents: Do you see a man who speaks in haste?
There is more hope for a fool than for him.

contents.verseText: A servant pampered from his youth will bring grief in the end.
contents: A servant pampered from his youth
will bring grief in the end.

contents.verseText: An angry man stirs up dissension, and a hot-tempered man abounds in transgression.
contents: An angry man stirs up dissension,
and a hot-tempered man abounds in transgression.

contents.verseText: A man’s pride will bring him low, but a humble spirit will obtain honor.
contents: A man’s pride will bring him low,
but a humble spirit will obtain honor.

contents.verseText: A partner to a thief hates his own soul; he receives the oath, but does not testify.
contents: A partner to a thief hates his own soul;
he receives the oath, but does not testify.

contents.verseText: The fear of man is a snare, but whoever trusts in the LORD is set securely on high.
contents: The fear of man is a snare,
but whoever trusts in the LORD is set securely on high.

contents.verseText: Many seek the ruler’s favor, but a man receives justice from the LORD.
contents: Many seek the ruler’s favor,
but a man receives justice from the LORD.

contents.verseText: An unjust man is detestable to the righteous, and one whose way is upright is detestable to the wicked.
contents: An unjust man is detestable to the righteous,
and one whose way is upright is detestable to the wicked.

contents.verseText: These are the words of Agur son of Jakeh—the burden that this man declared to Ithiel: “I am weary, O God, and worn out.
contents: These are the words of Agur son of Jakeh—the burden that this man declared to Ithiel:
“I am weary, O God,
and worn out.

footnote.ft: Or declared to Ithiel: “I am weary, O God, but I can prevail. (revocalizations); Hebrew declared to Ithiel—to Ithiel and Ucal:

contents.verseText: Surely I am the most ignorant of men, and I lack the understanding of a man.
contents: Surely I am the most ignorant of men,
and I lack the understanding of a man.

contents.verseText: I have not learned wisdom, and I have no knowledge of the Holy One.
contents: I have not learned wisdom,
and I have no knowledge of the Holy One.

contents.verseText: Who has ascended to heaven and come down? Who has gathered the wind in His hands? Who has bound up the waters in His cloak? Who has established all the ends of the earth? What is His name, and what is the name of His Son—surely you know!
contents: Who has ascended to heaven and come down?
Who has gathered the wind in His hands?
Who has bound up the waters in His cloak?
Who has established all the ends of the earth?
What is His name, and what is the name of His Son—
surely you know!

contents.verseText: Every word of God is flawless; He is a shield to those who take refuge in Him.
contents: Every word of God is flawless;
He is a shield to those who take refuge in Him.

contents.verseText: Do not add to His words, lest He rebuke you and prove you a liar.
contents: Do not add to His words,
lest He rebuke you and prove you a liar.

contents.verseText: Two things I ask of You—do not refuse me before I die:
contents: Two things I ask of You—
do not refuse me before I die:

contents.verseText: Keep falsehood and deceitful words far from me. Give me neither poverty nor riches; feed me with the bread that is my portion.
contents: Keep falsehood and deceitful words far from me.
Give me neither poverty nor riches;
feed me with the bread that is my portion.

contents.verseText: Otherwise, I may have too much and deny You, saying, ‘Who is the LORD?’ Or I may become poor and steal, profaning the name of my God.
contents: Otherwise, I may have too much
and deny You, saying, ‘Who is the LORD?’
Or I may become poor and steal,
profaning the name of my God.

contents.verseText: Do not slander a servant to his master, or he will curse you, and you will bear the guilt.
contents: Do not slander a servant to his master,
or he will curse you, and you will bear the guilt.

contents.verseText: There is a generation of those who curse their fathers and do not bless their mothers.
contents: There is a generation of those who curse their fathers
and do not bless their mothers.

contents.verseText: There is a generation of those who are pure in their own eyes and yet unwashed of their filth.
contents: There is a generation of those who are pure in their own eyes
and yet unwashed of their filth.

contents.verseText: There is a generation—how haughty are their eyes and pretentious are their glances—
contents: There is a generation—how haughty are their eyes
and pretentious are their glances—

contents.verseText: there is a generation whose teeth are swords and whose jaws are knives, devouring the oppressed from the earth and the needy from among men.
contents: there is a generation whose teeth are swords
and whose jaws are knives,
devouring the oppressed from the earth
and the needy from among men.

contents.verseText: The leech has two daughters: Give and Give. There are three things that are never satisfied, four that never say, ‘Enough!’: 1
contents: The leech has two daughters:
Give and Give.
There are three things that are never satisfied, four that never say, ‘Enough!’:

contents.verseText: Sheol, the barren womb, land never satisfied with water, and fire that never says, ‘Enough!’
contents: Sheol,

contents.verseText: As for the eye that mocks a father and scorns obedience to a mother, may the ravens of the valley pluck it out and young vultures devour it.
contents: As for the eye that mocks a father
and scorns obedience to a mother,
may the ravens of the valley pluck it out
and young vultures devour it.

contents.verseText: There are three things too wonderful for me, four that I cannot understand: 1
contents: There are three things too wonderful for me, four that I cannot understand:

contents.verseText: the way of an eagle in the sky, the way of a snake on a rock, the way of a ship at sea, and the way of a man with a maiden.
contents: the way of an eagle in the sky,

li1: the way of a snake on a rock,
the way of a ship at sea,
and the way of a man with a maiden.

contents.verseText: This is the way of an adulteress: She eats and wipes her mouth and says, ‘I have done nothing wrong.’
contents: This is the way of an adulteress:
She eats and wipes her mouth
and says, ‘I have done nothing wrong.’

contents.verseText: Under three things the earth trembles, under four it cannot bear up: 1
contents: Under three things the earth trembles, under four it cannot bear up:

contents.verseText: a servant who becomes king, a fool who is filled with food, 1
contents: a servant who becomes king,

li1: a fool who is filled with food,

contents.verseText: an unloved woman who marries, and a maidservant who supplants her mistress.
contents: an unloved woman who marries,

li1: and a maidservant who supplants her mistress.

contents.verseText: Four things on earth are small, yet they are exceedingly wise: 1
contents: Four things on earth are small, yet they are exceedingly wise:

contents.verseText: The ants are creatures of little strength, yet they store up their food in the summer; 1
contents: The ants are creatures of little strength, yet they store up their food in the summer;

contents.verseText: the rock badgers are creatures of little power, yet they make their homes in the rocks; 1
contents: the rock badgers

footnote.ft: Or the coneys or the hyraxes

contents: are creatures of little power, yet they make their homes in the rocks;

contents.verseText: the locusts have no king, yet they all advance in formation; 1
contents: the locusts have no king, yet they all advance in formation;

contents.verseText: and the lizard can be caught in one’s hands, yet it is found in the palaces of kings.
contents: and the lizard can be caught in one’s hands, yet it is found in the palaces of kings.

contents.verseText: There are three things that are stately in their stride, and four that are impressive in their walk: 1
contents: There are three things that are stately in their stride, and four that are impressive in their walk:

contents.verseText: a lion, mighty among beasts, refusing to retreat before anything; 1
contents: a lion, mighty among beasts, refusing to retreat before anything;

contents.verseText: a strutting rooster; a he-goat; and a king with his army around him.
contents: a strutting rooster;

li1: and a king with his army around him.

footnote.ft: Or a king against whom there is no rising up

contents.verseText: If you have foolishly exalted yourself or if you have plotted evil, put your hand over your mouth.
contents: If you have foolishly exalted yourself
or if you have plotted evil,
put your hand over your mouth.

contents.verseText: For as the churning of milk yields butter, and the twisting of the nose draws blood, so the stirring of anger brings forth strife.”
contents: For as the churning of milk yields butter,
and the twisting of the nose draws blood,
so the stirring of anger brings forth strife.”

contents.verseText: These are the words of King Lemuel—the burden that his mother taught him:
contents: These are the words of King Lemuel—the burden that his mother taught him:

contents.verseText: What shall I say, O my son? What, O son of my womb? What, O son of my vows?
contents: What shall I say,

footnote.ft: Or What or What are you doing

contents: O my son?
What, O son of my womb?
What, O son of my vows?

contents.verseText: Do not spend your strength on women or your vigor on those who ruin kings.
contents: Do not spend your strength on women
or your vigor on those who ruin kings.

contents.verseText: It is not for kings, O Lemuel, it is not for kings to drink wine, or for rulers to crave strong drink,
contents: It is not for kings, O Lemuel,
it is not for kings to drink wine,
or for rulers to crave strong drink,

contents.verseText: lest they drink and forget what is decreed, depriving all the oppressed of justice.
contents: lest they drink and forget what is decreed,
depriving all the oppressed of justice.

contents.verseText: Give strong drink to one who is perishing, and wine to the bitter in soul.
contents: Give strong drink to one who is perishing,
and wine to the bitter in soul.

contents.verseText: Let him drink and forget his poverty, and remember his misery no more.
contents: Let him drink and forget his poverty,
and remember his misery no more.

contents.verseText: Open your mouth for those with no voice, for the cause of all the dispossessed.
contents: Open your mouth for those with no voice,
for the cause of all the dispossessed.

contents.verseText: Open your mouth, judge righteously, and defend the cause of the poor and needy.
contents: Open your mouth, judge righteously,
and defend the cause of the poor and needy.

s1: The Virtues of a Noble Woman

contents.verseText: A wife of noble character, who can find? She is far more precious than rubies.
contents: A wife

footnote.ft: Verses 10–31 are an acrostic poem, each verse beginning with the successive letters of the Hebrew alphabet.

contents: of noble character, who can find?
She is far more precious than rubies.

contents.verseText: The heart of her husband trusts in her, and he lacks nothing of value.
contents: The heart of her husband trusts in her,
and he lacks nothing of value.

contents.verseText: She brings him good and not harm all the days of her life.
contents: She brings him good and not harm
all the days of her life.

contents.verseText: She selects wool and flax and works with eager hands.
contents: She selects wool and flax
and works with eager hands.

contents.verseText: She is like the merchant ships, bringing her food from afar.
contents: She is like the merchant ships,
bringing her food from afar.

contents.verseText: She rises while it is still night to provide food for her household and portions for her maidservants.
contents: She rises while it is still night
to provide food for her household
and portions for her maidservants.

contents.verseText: She appraises a field and buys it; from her earnings she plants a vineyard.
contents: She appraises a field and buys it;
from her earnings she plants a vineyard.

contents.verseText: She girds herself with strength and shows that her arms are strong.
contents: She girds herself

footnote.ft: Hebrew She girds her loins

contents: with strength
and shows that her arms are strong.

contents.verseText: She sees that her gain is good, and her lamp is not extinguished at night.
contents: She sees that her gain is good,
and her lamp is not extinguished at night.

contents.verseText: She stretches out her hands to the distaff and grasps the spindle with her fingers.
contents: She stretches out her hands to the distaff
and grasps the spindle with her fingers.

contents.verseText: She opens her arms to the poor and reaches out her hands to the needy.
contents: She opens her arms to the poor
and reaches out her hands to the needy.

contents.verseText: When it snows, she has no fear for her household, for they are all clothed in scarlet.
contents: When it snows, she has no fear for her household,
for they are all clothed in scarlet.

footnote.ft: Or doubly clothed

contents.verseText: She makes coverings for her bed; her clothing is fine linen and purple.
contents: She makes coverings for her bed;
her clothing is fine linen and purple.

contents.verseText: Her husband is known at the city gate, where he sits among the elders of the land.
contents: Her husband is known at the city gate,
where he sits among the elders of the land.

contents.verseText: She makes linen garments and sells them; she delivers sashes to the merchants.
contents: She makes linen garments and sells them;
she delivers sashes to the merchants.

contents.verseText: Strength and honor are her clothing, and she can laugh at the days to come.
contents: Strength and honor are her clothing,
and she can laugh at the days to come.

contents.verseText: She opens her mouth with wisdom, and faithful instruction is on her tongue.
contents: She opens her mouth with wisdom,
and faithful instruction is on her tongue.

contents.verseText: She watches over the affairs of her household and does not eat the bread of idleness.
contents: She watches over the affairs of her household
and does not eat the bread of idleness.

contents.verseText: Her children rise up and call her blessed; her husband praises her as well:
contents: Her children rise up and call her blessed;
her husband praises her as well:

contents.verseText: “Many daughters have done noble things, but you surpass them all!”
contents: “Many daughters have done noble things,
but you surpass them all!”

contents.verseText: Charm is deceptive and beauty is fleeting, but a woman who fears the LORD is to be praised.
contents: Charm is deceptive and beauty is fleeting,
but a woman who fears the LORD is to be praised.

contents.verseText: Give her the fruit of her hands, and let her works praise her at the gates.
contents: Give her the fruit of her hands,
and let her works praise her at the gates.
